quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.text: It's fascinating because if you ask someone to describe the mid-market, actually, if you ask someone to describe the enterprise, every single person has a different answer. It's either based off of revenue, it's either based off of market cap, it's based off of employee size, and I think a lot of people can get lost because selling to a hundred person organization is a radically different game than selling to a thousand person organization and there's no hybrid approach.

quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.text: Early adopters are those logos because they have to continue to stay at the number one spot. So they'll take tons of swings to continue to stay in the number one spot. Staying in the number one spot is the hardest part. So those number one logos are like if you can give me just a slight bit of alpha, just a tiny bit, that's where I get promoted.

quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.text: When you're selling to a leader, you need to be vision casting and you need to be selling an opportunity which is they are here, here's where we can take you. It's about selling the opportunity. That's what gets the tier one logos excited and that is the best thing for a founder to sell, selling the vision versus the problem.

quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.text: The best clients are not going to do that to you because that's like a qualification criteria, which is like if they're sitting there nickel-and-diming you being like, 'No, I don't believe it's worth this. I don't believe it's worth that.' They're not fully bought in on what you're selling them.

quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.text: Enterprise companies are very used to a land, when I say the first initial contract, somewhat between 75K and 150K, very used to that. Start contained, don't say 150K and sell the farm. Say, 'It's 150K, here's who gets access, here's the value we're going to deliver and here's where we're going over time.' You also want them to know, 'Here's what we plan to do roughly in year two, year three.'

quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.text: Design partners are incredible. They're the hardest logos to upsell, meaning go from design partner to full rollout customer. So don't expect these people to be your million dollar pipeline. Expect these people to be the guide, to help you understand.

quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.text: The founder's job is to have a clear vision and do not let anything delineate from that. It's important to take feedback in terms of what is the market's reality, but it is the founder's job to interpret that because a lot of feedback you get is this is the old way, they're responding this way because it's the old way of working.

quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.text: From one to 10, I think it's more of an art, which is how do I take my learning and how do I package it up where I own the framing, I can speak to very specific alpha, I can vision cast and where I better understand the problem over time better than the market does. And it's all about deal crafting.

quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.text: As soon as you become a comparison, as soon as you become one of three that they're testing out, you've already sort of lost. It's all about differentiation and it's all about here's what you will be able to do tomorrow because of how we're going to serve you today.

quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.text: The market doesn't want to be sold to, they want to buy. And I know that it's very hard to hire a really good enterprise salesperson. The number of people that I've interviewed, I can count on my hand the ones that I get really, really excited by.

quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.text: The thing about AI tools is they're all pulling from the same databases. So I'm like, 'I want to email someone not in the database that's getting hit by a million folks. I want to take a back door in, not the front door where everyone else is trick-or-treating.'

quotes.speaker: Jen Abel
quotes.text: Don't be better. Be different. The whole game is about, 'Oh, this feels different. That's what people want access to.' Yet everyone commoditizes themselves. They try and mimic what everyone else is doing. Everyone gets excited by the new because the new could be the next thing, the thing that changes it all.

takeaways: The mid-market doesn't exist — know whether you're playing the SMB or enterprise game and don't try to blend them.
Tier one logos are actually early adopters because they need to maintain their market leadership, making them more willing to take swings on new technology.
Vision cast instead of problem-sell — enterprise buyers want to be shown an opportunity and future alpha, not just a fix for a specific pain point.
Land your first enterprise deal between $75K-$150K; pricing too low anchors you and makes expansion nearly impossible to defend.
Great enterprise salespeople cosplay the founder — they sell the vision, build relationships through trust, and craft creative deals rather than following scripts.

contrarian_candidates.why: Conventional wisdom says startups should go after small companies first; Jen argues tier one enterprise logos are actually the early adopters.
While everyone rushes to adopt AI SDR tools, Jen deliberately avoids them and does manual outbound because AI tools pull from the same databases.
Challenges the default startup mindset of being 'better' — insists the game is about being different, not incrementally superior.
